headline: Paramount sweetens WBD buyout offer, Spotify surges on user growth
summary: Morning Brief Host Julie Hyman tracks several of the day's top trending stock tickers, including Paramount Skydance (PSKY) upping its buyout offer to Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) with a new "ticking fee," Spotify (SPOT) shares surging in Tuesday's premarket after reporting record user growth in its fourth quarter and full-year 2025, and Harley Davidson (HOG) stock dropping after releasing sales figures that fell below expectations. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: Paramount sweetens WBD buyout offer, Spotify surges on user growth

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery stock rises after Paramount sweetens takeover offer
summary: Investing.com -- Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. (NASDAQ:WBD) stock rose 2% Tuesday after Paramount Skydance Corporation (NASDAQ:PSKY) enhanced its $30 per share all-cash takeover offer with additional financial incentives.

content.title: Warner Bros. Discovery stock rises after Paramount sweetens takeover offer
content.summary: Investing.com -- Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. (NASDAQ:WBD) stock rose 2% Tuesday after Paramount Skydance Corporation (NASDAQ:PSKY) enhanced its $30 per share all-cash takeover offer with additional financial incentives.

headline: PARAMOUNT ENHANCES ITS SUPERIOR $30 PER SHARE ALL-CASH OFFER FOR WARNER BROS. DISCOVERY AND PROVIDES UPDATE ON REGULATORY PROGRESS
summary: Paramount Skydance Corporation (NASDAQ: PSKY) ("Paramount") today announced it has amended its $30 per share, all-cash tender offer to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. (NASDAQ: WBD) ("WBD") with enhancements that surpass the standard needed for the WBD Board to engage on Paramount's superior proposal.

content.title: PARAMOUNT ENHANCES ITS SUPERIOR $30 PER SHARE ALL-CASH OFFER FOR WARNER BROS. DISCOVERY AND PROVIDES UPDATE ON REGULATORY PROGRESS
content.summary: Paramount Skydance Corporation (NASDAQ: PSKY) ("Paramount") today announced it has amended its $30 per share, all-cash tender offer to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. (NASDAQ: WBD) ("WBD") with enhancements that surpass the standard needed for the WBD Board to engage on Paramount's superior proposal.

headline: Paramount Sweetens Warner Offer
summary: The media company, which is pursuing a hostile bid for Warner, also said it complied with Justice Department request for information about its proposed deal.

content.title: Paramount Sweetens Warner Offer
content.summary: The media company, which is pursuing a hostile bid for Warner, also said it complied with Justice Department request for information about its proposed deal.

headline: Paramount sweetens Warner Bros bid with ticking fee, Netflix break-up fee cover
summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close after this year and agreed to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  Even though Paramount did not raise ​its per-share offer, the sweeteners mark the company's latest attempt to woo Warner Bros shareholders in its prolonged battle with Netflix for control of some of the world's most ‌prized TV and film assets.  The CBS parent has offered a 25-cent per share "ticking fee" that will equal to about $650 million in cash each quarter between the start of 2027 and the close of a deal with Warner Bros, Paramount said ‌in on Tuesday.

content.title: Paramount sweetens Warner Bros bid with ticking fee, Netflix break-up fee cover
content.summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close after this year and agreed to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  Even though Paramount did not raise ​its per-share offer, the sweeteners mark the company's latest attempt to woo Warner Bros shareholders in its prolonged battle with Netflix for control of some of the world's most ‌prized TV and film assets.  The CBS parent has offered a 25-cent per share "ticking fee" that will equal to about $650 million in cash each quarter between the start of 2027 and the close of a deal with Warner Bros, Paramount said ‌in on Tuesday.

headline: Paramount Sweetens Warner Bros. Bid Terms to Woo Investors
summary: Paramount said in a statement on Tuesday it will cover the $2.8 billion termination fee that Warner Bros. will have to pay to Netflix if it ends the already agreed-upon deal with the streaming giant.  It will also backstop a Warner Bros. debt refinancing and pay $1.5 billion in fees associated with that, if necessary.

content.title: Paramount Sweetens Warner Bros. Bid Terms to Woo Investors
content.summary: Paramount said in a statement on Tuesday it will cover the $2.8 billion termination fee that Warner Bros. will have to pay to Netflix if it ends the already agreed-upon deal with the streaming giant.  It will also backstop a Warner Bros. debt refinancing and pay $1.5 billion in fees associated with that, if necessary.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery Confirms Receipt of Further Amended Unsolicited Tender Offer from Paramount Skydance
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. ("Warner Bros. Discovery" or "WBD") (NASDAQ: WBD) today confirmed that it has received an amended, unsolicited tender offer from Paramount Skydance Corporation ("Paramount Skydance" or "PSKY") (NASDAQ: PSKY) to acquire all of the outstanding shares of WBD common stock (the "February 10 Amended Tender Offer").

content.title: Warner Bros. Discovery Confirms Receipt of Further Amended Unsolicited Tender Offer from Paramount Skydance
content.summary: Warner Bros. Discovery, Inc. ("Warner Bros. Discovery" or "WBD") (NASDAQ: WBD) today confirmed that it has received an amended, unsolicited tender offer from Paramount Skydance Corporation ("Paramount Skydance" or "PSKY") (NASDAQ: PSKY) to acquire all of the outstanding shares of WBD common stock (the "February 10 Amended Tender Offer").

headline: Paramount Puts Its Money Where Its Mouth Is With New Warner Bros. Offer
summary: Paramount submitted a new offer for Warner Bros. that added clauses meant to demonstrate its belief it could close the deal quickly.

content.title: Paramount Puts Its Money Where Its Mouth Is With New Warner Bros. Offer
content.summary: Paramount submitted a new offer for Warner Bros. that added clauses meant to demonstrate its belief it could close the deal quickly.

headline: Paramount sweetens offer to Warner Bros shareholders in hostile takeover fight
summary: Paramount is again sweetening its hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, while again extending the deadline for its tender offer as it scrambles for more shareholder support.  Paramount also pledged to fund Warner's proposed $2.8 billion breakup payout to Netflix under its studio and streaming merger agreement.  The value of Paramount's offer otherwise remains unchanged.

content.title: Paramount sweetens offer to Warner Bros shareholders in hostile takeover fight
content.summary: Paramount is again sweetening its hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, while again extending the deadline for its tender offer as it scrambles for more shareholder support.  Paramount also pledged to fund Warner's proposed $2.8 billion breakup payout to Netflix under its studio and streaming merger agreement.  The value of Paramount's offer otherwise remains unchanged.

headline: Instant View: Paramount adds sweeteners to Warner Bros bid
summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close beyond this year and agreeing ​to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  WBD shareholders will likely only be swayed by a significant increase in the current $30/share offer from Paramount.  The ‍updated offer addresses two big concerns/wants: one from WBD shareholders regarding the length of time needed to secure regulatory approval for a purchase and two from WBD management's demand for PSKY to pay for the breakup fee with NFLX.

content.title: Instant View: Paramount adds sweeteners to Warner Bros bid
content.summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close beyond this year and agreeing ​to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  WBD shareholders will likely only be swayed by a significant increase in the current $30/share offer from Paramount.  The ‍updated offer addresses two big concerns/wants: one from WBD shareholders regarding the length of time needed to secure regulatory approval for a purchase and two from WBD management's demand for PSKY to pay for the breakup fee with NFLX.

headline: Paramount sweetens Warner Bros bid with offer to pay Netflix break-up cost, other fees
summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering shareholders extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close after this year and agreeing to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  Even though Paramount did not raise its per-share offer, the sweeteners mark the ​company's latest attempt to woo Warner Bros shareholders in its prolonged battle with Netflix for control of some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.  Paramount has offered to pay shareholders a 25-cent ‌per share "ticking fee" that will equal about $650 million in cash each quarter between the start of 2027 and the close of a deal with Warner Bros, the company said on Tuesday, in what appeared to be a sign of its confidence in getting a deal done relatively ‌quickly.

content.title: Paramount sweetens Warner Bros bid with offer to pay Netflix break-up cost, other fees
content.summary: Paramount Skydance has enhanced its Warner Bros Discovery bid by offering shareholders extra cash for each quarter the deal fails to close after this year and agreeing to cover the breakup fee the HBO owner would owe Netflix if it walked away.  Even though Paramount did not raise its per-share offer, the sweeteners mark the ​company's latest attempt to woo Warner Bros shareholders in its prolonged battle with Netflix for control of some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.  Paramount has offered to pay shareholders a 25-cent ‌per share "ticking fee" that will equal about $650 million in cash each quarter between the start of 2027 and the close of a deal with Warner Bros, the company said on Tuesday, in what appeared to be a sign of its confidence in getting a deal done relatively ‌quickly.
